item.title: QeHDC: Hyperdimensional Computing based on Quantum-enhanced binding and SuperClass Construction (To NeurIPS)
Quantum-StateHD: Leveraging Random Quantum States for Hyperdimensional Computing (IJCNN)
Quantum Machine Learning
item.description:
‚öõÔ∏è Quantum Machine Learning (QML) is where the surreal beauty of quantum physics meets the power of artificial intelligence.

What is Quantum Machine Learning?

Quantum Machine Learning (QML) is an emerging interdisciplinary field that combines quantum computing with machine learning techniques. It aims to explore:

‚ÄúCan quantum computers accelerate or enhance the capabilities of traditional machine learning models?‚Äù

Key ideas behind QML include:

  • Encoding classical data into quantum states
  • Designing trainable quantum circuits
  • Using hybrid quantum-classical training loops

Why Does QML Matter?

Quantum computers offer exponential parallelism in certain scenarios. Potential benefits of QML include:

item.title: Quantum-Classical Hybrid Neural Network for Yield Prediction (to ICONIP2025)
LeetCode Solution: N-Queens
item.description:
üëë Problem: N-Queens

Description: The N-Queens puzzle is the problem of placing n queens on an n x n chessboard such that no two queens attack each other. Return all distinct solutions to the N-Queens puzzle.

Example:

Input: n = 4
Output: [[".Q..","...Q","Q...","..Q."]]

üß† Algorithm Explanation

This is a classic backtracking problem, which we solve using an explicit stack to avoid recursive or nested functions. Each item on the stack holds:

item.title: Quantum Shadow Learning For Cropland Classification (ICMI)
LeetCode Solution: Word Ladder
item.description:
üß© Problem: Word Ladder

Description: Given two words, beginWord and endWord, and a dictionary word list, return the length of the shortest transformation sequence from beginWord to endWord, such that:

  • Only one letter can be changed at a time.
  • Each transformed word must exist in the word list.

Example:

Input: beginWord = "hit", endWord = "cog", wordList = ["hot","dot","dog","lot","log","cog"]
Output: 5  # "hit" -> "hot" -> "dot" -> "dog" -> "cog"

üß† Algorithm Explanation

This is a shortest-path problem in an unweighted graph. Each word is a node, and there is an edge between two words if they differ by one letter. We use Breadth-First Search (BFS) from beginWord to find the shortest path to endWord. To speed up, we precompute generic patterns like h*t, ho* etc. to represent transformations.

item.title: LeetCode Solution: Trapping Rain Water
item.description:
üíß Problem: Trapping Rain Water

Description: Given n non-negative integers representing an elevation map where the width of each bar is 1, compute how much water it can trap after raining.

Example:

Input: height = [0,1,0,2,1,0,1,3,2,1,2,1]
Output: 6

üß† Algorithm Explanation

To calculate trapped water at every index i, we need to find:

  • The maximum height on the left of i
  • The maximum height on the right of i
  • Water trapped at i = min(left_max, right_max) - height[i]

To improve efficiency:
